docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: By getting ''good news'' that she did not test positive for the BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation, the writer of ''Sometimes It's the Good News'' was fortunate not to have to make radical decisions on her health care. She was also lucky because her insurer and employer would not have information to discriminate against her.
docs.abstract: Letter from Steven P Scalici recalls how thoughtful and caring people were to him when he battled cancer (Aug 7 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    By getting ''good news'' that she did not test positive for the BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation, the writer of ''Sometimes It's the Good News'' was fortunate not to have to make radical decisions on her health care. She was also lucky...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''When Medical Devices Fail in the Body'' (Aug. 7): A manufacturer has admitted that it produced a number of defective artificial hip implants, then goes on to state that it will pay for the operations to replace the implants if they are not covered by the patients' insurance. Wait a minute. Why is anyone's insurance being asked to pay for what is clearly the company's responsibility? People and small businesses with experience-based health insurance policies have their premiums (and their very insurability) based on prior claims.
docs.abstract: Letter from Lloyd Mills, prompted by Aug 7 article in defective implants, says manufacturers, not health insurance companies, should pay for operations to replace bad implants
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''When Medical Devices Fail in the Body'' (Aug. 7): A manufacturer has admitted that it produced a number of defective artificial hip implants, then goes on to state that it will pay for the operations to replace the implants if...

docs.lead_paragraph: They get CAT scans and M.R.I.'s to detect the extent of cancer; lithotripsy to dissolve kidney and bladder stones; dialysis and transplants for kidney failure; surgery, chemotherapy and even radiation therapy to treat cancer; laser surgery for glaucoma; pacemakers to correct abnormal heart rhythms; ultrasonic surgery and lens implants for cataracts; root canal therapy for broken teeth; chiropractic treatments for sore backs; spinal surgery for ruptured disks, and arthroscopic surgery and cartilage cell transplants for crippling knee problems. They are treated in intensive care units for respiratory, kidney or liver failure; they run on treadmills to test heart function, and they take Prozac-type drugs for separation anxiety, Anipryl for senility, Tagamet for ulcers, insulin shots for diabetes, hormones for anemia, and steroids and antibiotics for irritable bowel syndrome.

headline.main: V.I.P. Medical Treatment Adds Meaning to a Dog's (or Cat's) Life

docs.abstract: Nearly every medical procedure now done on humans, including kidney transplants, is being used or at least studied at nation's leading companion animal medical centers to accommodate growing number of pet owners who are willing to spend thousands of dollars on their animals' health; value of companion animals to their owners goes way beyond dogs and cats; Dr Ann Hohenhaus, veterinarian, says people now spend thousands of dollars on treatment for turtles, guinea pigs, hamsters, gerbils, snakes, lizards, birds and ferrets as well; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If ever there was a free market, it is here on Revolution Avenue. A short walk from the American border, surrounded by gaudy bars and gewgaws, hundreds of pharmacies sell millions of dollars' worth of medicine for a song.

headline.main: In Tijuana, a New Kind of Drug Peril

docs.abstract: Tijuana, Mexico, has become popular destination for Americans seeking inexpensive medicines; border pharmacies have boomed since mid-1990's, ever since Pres Clinton's health-care plan collapsed, managed-care and health maintenance organizations came to dominate American medicine, and prescription drug costs started climbing 10 to 15 percent annually; seem like godsend to older Americans seeking prescription drugs they cannot afford back in US, only major developed nation without price or profit controls on medicine; boom is beginning to adversely impact global market in counterfeit, adulterated and stolen medicine that mimics international narcotics trade; shelves hold medicines that have been donated or sold at cost to poor countries, stolen by corrupt officials, then diverted to Mexico; photo (M)
docs.snippet: If ever there was a free market, it is here on Revolution Avenue.    A short walk from the American border, surrounded by gaudy bars and gewgaws, hundreds of pharmacies sell millions of dollars' worth of medicine for a song.

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: State officials are expressing grave doubts about federal legislation on patients' rights, especially a bill passed by the House this month, saying it would override state laws that provide greater protection to millions of consumers. With President Bush's intensive participation, Congress is writing the first comprehensive federal standards for health insurance. How to mesh the federal and state roles is a big political, legal and technical challenge that could determine the ultimate success of any new federal law.

headline.main: STATES DISMAYED BY FEDERAL BILLS ON PATIENT RIGHTS

docs.abstract: State officials from both parties are expressing grave doubts about federal legislation on patients' rights, especially bill passed by House, saying it would override state laws that provide greater protection to millions of consumers; Congress is writing first comprehensive federal standard for health insurance with Pres Bush's intensive participation, but how to mesh federal and state roles remains big political, legal and technical challenge that could determine ultimate success of any new federal law; has been debating legislation over past six years to regulate managed care, and most states have since adopted laws to do so; 40 states have laws that guarantee patients independent medical review if they are denied care by health insurance plans; 10 have passed laws giving patients right to sue for damages caused by delay or denial of care (M)
docs.snippet: State officials are expressing grave doubts about federal legislation on patients' rights, especially a bill passed by the House this month, saying it would override state laws that provide greater protection to millions of consumers.    With...

docs.lead_paragraph: The splintering of endorsements from black elected officials, religious leaders and civic groups in the mayor's race continued yesterday. One of Harlem's prominent ministers, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts, said he was supporting Mark Green's bid for the Democratic nomination, while a fraternal organization of black police officers threw its weight behind one of Mr. Green's three rivals, Alan G. Hevesi. The two endorsements -- one offered outside the Abyssinian Baptist Church on West 138th Street, where Mr. Butts presides, the other on the steps of City Hall -- came as another Democratic mayoral candidate, Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, repeated yesterday that he was still soliciting the backing of several black leaders, including the Rev. Al Sharpton.

headline.main: Black Leaders Continue Spreading Out Their Mayoral Endorsements

docs.abstract: Black elected officials, religious leaders and civic groups are splintering their endorsements in New York City mayor's race, reflecting growing geographic and economic diversity among blacks in city today; Harlem, once dominant base of black political power, must share that power now with southeast Queens and central Brooklyn; Alan Hevesi has won backing of Rev Floyd Flake, paster of huge black church in Jamaica, Queens, as well as that of Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr, leader of Brooklyn Democratic Party, and fraternal organization of black police officers; Mark Green has won backing of former Mayor David N Dinkins and Assemblyman Herman D Farrell Jr, chairman of Manhattan Democratic Party, and Rev Calvin O Butts; Fernando Ferrer is courting endorsement of Rev Al Sharpton; Peter Vallone cites list of 22 black pastors who support his campaign, including Rev Alfloyd Alston of Harlem; various endorsements among black leaders proves confusing to some voters (M)
docs.snippet: The splintering of endorsements from black elected officials, religious leaders and civic groups in the mayor's race continued yesterday. One of Harlem's prominent ministers, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts, said he was supporting Mark Green's bid for the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Melinda Ballard parks her cream-colored Jaguar next to her deserted dream house in Dripping Springs, Tex. -- a house she fled more than two years ago, leaving dirty dishes in the sink and unopened mail on the counter. Popping open the Jag's trunk, she pulls out two portable respirator masks. ''These won't screen out all the mycotoxins,'' she warns as she tosses one to me. ''That's the dangerous stuff, so we'll only stay a few minutes.'' I follow as she wades through the strawlike remains of what was once a manicured garden, past the abandoned pool, the empty hot tub and the exquisite leaded glass that frames the front door. A sign on that door warns that we should really be wearing full Tyvek biohazard ''moon suits'' too, but this is a Texas summer, and we would probably die of heatstroke before the mycotoxins could get us. So we each fit a heavy black contraption over our noses and mouths, pull the elastic tight to form a seal and snap on our rubber gloves.
docs.abstract: Article on toxic molds that are invading homes, schools, offices and other buildings and which seem to be making people sick; focuses on case of Melinda Ballard and husband, Ron Allison, whose dream house in Dripping Springs, Tex, and condominium in Santa Ana, Calif, are loaded with slimy black growth with names like Stachybotrys chartarum, Aspergillus and Penicillium; scientists say mold usually develops when steady and significant amounts of water, commonly from roof leak or unnoticed burst pipe, comes in contact with cellulose-based wallboard; work of Bill Holder and others of new breed of experts on toxic building mold; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Melinda Ballard parks her cream-colored Jaguar next to her deserted dream house in Dripping Springs, Tex. -- a house she fled more than two years ago, leaving dirty dishes in the sink and unopened mail on the counter. Popping open the Jag's trunk,...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the lounge of his brothel, Andre van Dorst sits in the glow of a red lamp shaped like a huge voluptuous mouth and slaps document after document on the table -- from the health department, from the police, from the tax department, the labor department. ''They just go on and on,'' he fumes. ''This one says how the girls have to wash their frilly underthings in practically boiling water. And this one says they have to cut their nails very short. For hygiene purposes, of course. And here they have to have a pillow in the room. You don't want a pillow in your room. It's a murder weapon.''

headline.main: New Rights for Dutch Prostitutes, but No Gain

docs.abstract: Netherlands, where prostitution has long been legal, has now legalized brothels and is trying to devise regulatory system; new law is intended to help police control industry and grant labor rights and protections to more than 30,000 working prostitutes, but many are now complaining about stupid bureaucratic rules and regulations that may force operations to close down or go underground; prostitutes trying to set themselves up as self-employed businesswomen are being turned down by accountants, banks and health insurance companies; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: KEVIN MAY, a traveling nurse, was educated in Canada, and in the last two years has worked in North Carolina, New Mexico and now Connecticut. At Yale-New Haven Hospital, he works on medical or surgical floors, tending to patients who are recovering from surgery or an illness. Mr. May is not a Yale-New Haven employee; rather, he works for Cross Country Travcorps, an agency in Boca Raton, Fla., that places nurses wherever they are needed.

headline.main: Wanted: More Than a Few Good Nurses

docs.abstract: Article on nursing shortage in Connecticut, where some hospitals have dramatically increased their use of traveling nurses over last two years; health experts cite managed care and decrease in reimbursements to hospitals from insurance companies as major factor in shortage; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Laura Baynon Hardman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Barnett Hardman of Atlanta, was married yesterday to John Richard Collins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Byron Collins of Worcester, Mass. The Very Rev. Samuel G. Candler performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip in Atlanta. The bride and bridegroom met at Princeton University, where they graduated, she summa cum laude, he cum laude.
